paragraph: CHAPTER 14. The First Blow
tokens: first blow

paragraph: I WAS so pleased at having given the slip to Long John that I began to enjoy myself and look around me with some interest on the strange land that I was in.
tokens: pleased give slip long begin enjoy look interest strange land

paragraph: I had crossed a marshy tract full of willows, bulrushes, and odd, outlandish, swampy trees; and I had now come out upon the skirts of an open piece of undulating, sandy country, about a mile long, dotted with a few pines and a great number of contorted trees, not unlike the oak in growth, but pale in the foliage, like willows. On the far side of the open stood one of the hills, with two quaint, craggy peaks shining vividly in the sun.
tokens: cross marshy tract full willow bulrushe odd outlandish swampy tree come skirt open piece undulate sandy country mile long dot few pine great number contort tree oak growth pale foliage willow far side open stand hill quaint craggy peak shine sun

paragraph: I now felt for the first time the joy of exploration. The isle was uninhabited; my shipmates I had left behind, and nothing lived in front of me but dumb brutes and fowls. I turned hither and thither among the trees. Here and there were flowering plants, unknown to me; here and there I saw snakes, and one raised his head from a ledge of rock and hissed at me with a noise not unlike the spinning of a top. Little did I suppose that he was a deadly enemy and that the noise was the famous rattle.
tokens: feel first time joy exploration isle uninhabited shipmate leave live front dumb brute fowl turn tree be flower plant unknown see snake raise head ledge rock hiss noise spinning top suppose deadly enemy noise famous rattle

paragraph: Then I came to a long thicket of these oaklike trees--live, or evergreen, oaks, I heard afterwards they should be called--which grew low along the sand like brambles, the boughs curiously twisted, the foliage compact, like thatch. The thicket stretched down from the top of one of the sandy knolls, spreading and growing taller as it went, until it reached the margin of the broad, reedy fen, through which the nearest of the little rivers soaked its way into the anchorage. The marsh was steaming in the strong sun, and the outline of the Spy-glass trembled through the haze.
tokens: come long thicket oaklike tree live evergreen oak hear call grow low sand bramble bough twist foliage compact like thatch thicket stretch top sandy knoll spread grow tall go reach margin broad reedy fen near little river soak way anchorage marsh steam strong sun outline glass tremble haze

paragraph: All at once there began to go a sort of bustle among the bulrushes; a wild duck flew up with a quack, another followed, and soon over the whole surface of the marsh a great cloud of birds hung screaming and circling in the air. I judged at once that some of my shipmates must be drawing near along the borders of the fen. Nor was I deceived, for soon I heard the very distant and low tones of a human voice, which, as I continued to give ear, grew steadily louder and nearer.
tokens: begin go sort bustle bulrushe wild duck fly quack follow whole surface marsh great cloud bird hang scream circle air judge shipmate draw border fen deceive hear distant low tone human voice continue give ear grow louder nearer

paragraph: This put me in a great fear, and I crawled under cover of the nearest live-oak and squatted there, hearkening, as silent as a mouse.
tokens: put great fear crawl cover near live oak squatet hearken silent mouse

paragraph: Another voice answered, and then the first voice, which I now recognized to be Silver's, once more took up the story and ran on for a long while in a stream, only now and again interrupted by the other. By the sound they must have been talking earnestly, and almost fiercely; but no distinct word came to my hearing.
tokens: voice answer first voice recognize take story run long while stream interrupt other sound talk distinct word come hearing

paragraph: At last the speakers seemed to have paused and perhaps to have sat down, for not only did they cease to draw any nearer, but the birds themselves began to grow more quiet and to settle again to their places in the swamp.
tokens: last speaker seem pause sit cease draw nearer bird begin grow quiet settle place swamp

paragraph: And now I began to feel that I was neglecting my business, that since I had been so foolhardy as to come ashore with these desperadoes, the least I could do was to overhear them at their councils, and that my plain and obvious duty was to draw as close as I could manage, under the favourable ambush of the crouching trees.
tokens: begin feel neglect business foolhardy come desperadoe least do overhear council plain obvious duty draw manage favourable ambush crouching tree

paragraph: I could tell the direction of the speakers pretty exactly, not only by the sound of their voices but by the behaviour of the few birds that still hung in alarm above the heads of the intruders.
tokens: tell direction speaker sound voice behaviour few bird hang alarm head intruder

paragraph: Crawling on all fours, I made steadily but slowly towards them, till at last, raising my head to an aperture among the leaves, I could see clear down into a little green dell beside the marsh, and closely set about with trees, where Long John Silver and another of the crew stood face to face in conversation.
tokens: crawl four make last raise head aperture leave see clear little green dell marsh set tree long crew stand face face conversation

paragraph: The sun beat full upon them. Silver had thrown his hat beside him on the ground, and his great, smooth, blond face, all shining with heat, was lifted to the other man's in a kind of appeal.
tokens: sun beat full throw hat ground great smooth blond face shine heat lift other man kind appeal

paragraph: "Mate," he was saying, "it's because I thinks gold dust of you--gold dust, and you may lay to that! If I hadn't took to you like pitch, do you think I'd have been here a-warning of you? All's up--you can't make nor mend; it's to save your neck that I'm a-speaking, and if one of the wild uns knew it, where'd I be, Tom--now, tell me, where'd I be?"
tokens: say think gold dust gold dust lay take pitch think warning make mend save neck speak wild uns know tell

paragraph: "Silver," said the other man--and I observed he was not only red in the face, but spoke as hoarse as a crow, and his voice shook too, like a taut rope--"Silver," says he, "you're old, and you're honest, or has the name for it; and you've money too, which lots of poor sailors hasn't; and you're brave, or I'm mistook. And will you tell me you'll let yourself be led away with that kind of a mess of swabs? Not you! As sure as God sees me, I'd sooner lose my hand. If I turn agin my dooty--"
tokens: silver say other man observe red face speak hoarse crow voice shake taut rope say old honest have name have money lot poor sailor brave mistake tell let lead kind mess swab sure see lose hand turn dooty

paragraph: And then all of a sudden he was interrupted by a noise. I had found one of the honest hands--well, here, at that same moment, came news of another. Far away out in the marsh there arose, all of a sudden, a sound like the cry of anger, then another on the back of it; and then one horrid, long-drawn scream. The rocks of the Spy-glass re-echoed it a score of times; the whole troop of marsh-birds rose again, darkening heaven, with a simultaneous whirr; and long after that death yell was still ringing in my brain, silence had re-established its empire, and only the rustle of the redescending birds and the boom of the distant surges disturbed the languor of the afternoon.
tokens: interrupt noise find honest hand same moment come news marsh arise sudden sound cry anger back horrid long draw scream rock glass re-echoe score time whole troop marsh bird rise darken heaven simultaneous whirr death yell ring brain silence re-establish empire rustle redescend bird boom distant surge disturb languor afternoon

paragraph: Tom had leaped at the sound, like a horse at the spur, but Silver had not winked an eye. He stood where he was, resting lightly on his crutch, watching his companion like a snake about to spring.
tokens: leap sound horse spur wink eye stand rest crutch watch companion snake spring

paragraph: "John!" said the sailor, stretching out his hand.
tokens: say sailor stretch hand

paragraph: "Hands off!" cried Silver, leaping back a yard, as it seemed to me, with the speed and security of a trained gymnast.
tokens: hand cry leap yard seem speed security train gymnast

paragraph: "Hands off, if you like, John Silver," said the other. "It's a black conscience that can make you feared of me. But in heaven's name, tell me, what was that?"
tokens: hand like say other black conscience make fear heaven name tell

paragraph: "That?" returned Silver, smiling away, but warier than ever, his eye a mere pin-point in his big face, but gleaming like a crumb of glass. "That? Oh, I reckon that'll be Alan."
tokens: return smile wary eye mere pin-point big face gleam crumb glass reckon

paragraph: And at this point Tom flashed out like a hero.
tokens: point flash hero

paragraph: "Alan!" he cried. "Then rest his soul for a true seaman! And as for you, John Silver, long you've been a mate of mine, but you're mate of mine no more. If I die like a dog, I'll die in my dooty. You've killed Alan, have you? Kill me too, if you can. But I defies you."
tokens: cry rest soul true seaman mate mate more die dog die dooty kill kill defie

paragraph: And with that, this brave fellow turned his back directly on the cook and set off walking for the beach. But he was not destined to go far. With a cry John seized the branch of a tree, whipped the crutch out of his armpit, and sent that uncouth missile hurtling through the air. It struck poor Tom, point foremost, and with stunning violence, right between the shoulders in the middle of his back. His hands flew up, he gave a sort of gasp, and fell.
tokens: brave fellow turn back cook set walking beach destine go cry seize branch tree whip crutch armpit send uncouth missile hurtle air strike poor point foremost stunning violence shoulder middle back hand fly give sort gasp fall

paragraph: Whether he were injured much or little, none could ever tell. Like enough, to judge from the sound, his back was broken on the spot. But he had no time given him to recover. Silver, agile as a monkey even without leg or crutch, was on the top of him next moment and had twice buried his knife up to the hilt in that defenceless body. From my place of ambush, I could hear him pant aloud as he struck the blows.
tokens: injure much little tell enough judge sound back break spot have time give recover silver agile monkey leg crutch top next moment bury knife hilt defenceless body place ambush hear pant strike blow

paragraph: I do not know what it rightly is to faint, but I do know that for the next little while the whole world swam away from before me in a whirling mist; Silver and the birds, and the tall Spy-glass hilltop, going round and round and topsy-turvy before my eyes, and all manner of bells ringing and distant voices shouting in my ear.
tokens: know faint know next little whole world swim whirl mist bird tall spy glass hilltop go topsy turvy eye manner bell ring distant voice shouting ear

paragraph: When I came again to myself the monster had pulled himself together, his crutch under his arm, his hat upon his head. Just before him Tom lay motionless upon the sward; but the murderer minded him not a whit, cleansing his blood-stained knife the while upon a wisp of grass. Everything else was unchanged, the sun still shining mercilessly on the steaming marsh and the tall pinnacle of the mountain, and I could scarce persuade myself that murder had been actually done and a human life cruelly cut short a moment since before my eyes.
tokens: come monster pull crutch arm hat head lay motionless sward murderer minded whit cleanse blood stain knife while wisp grass else unchanged sun shine steam marsh tall pinnacle mountain persuade murder do human life cut short moment eye

paragraph: But now John put his hand into his pocket, brought out a whistle, and blew upon it several modulated blasts that rang far across the heated air. I could not tell, of course, the meaning of the signal, but it instantly awoke my fears. More men would be coming. I might be discovered. They had already slain two of the honest people; after Tom and Alan, might not I come next?
tokens: put hand pocket bring whistle blow several modulate blast ring heat air tell course meaning signal awoke fear more man come discover slain honest person come

paragraph: Instantly I began to extricate myself and crawl back again, with what speed and silence I could manage, to the more open portion of the wood. As I did so, I could hear hails coming and going between the old buccaneer and his comrades, and this sound of danger lent me wings. As soon as I was clear of the thicket, I ran as I never ran before, scarce minding the direction of my flight, so long as it led me from the murderers; and as I ran, fear grew and grew upon me until it turned into a kind of frenzy.
tokens: begin extricate crawl speed silence manage open portion wood do hear hail come go old buccaneer comrade sound danger loan wing clear thicket run run scarce mind direction flight lead murderer run fear grow grow turn kind frenzy

paragraph: Indeed, could anyone be more entirely lost than I? When the gun fired, how should I dare to go down to the boats among those fiends, still smoking from their crime? Would not the first of them who saw me wring my neck like a snipe's? Would not my absence itself be an evidence to them of my alarm, and therefore of my fatal knowledge? It was all over, I thought. Good-bye to the HISPANIOLA; good-bye to the squire, the doctor, and the captain! There was nothing left for me but death by starvation or death by the hands of the mutineers.
tokens: lose gun fire dare go boat fiend smoke crime first see wring neck snipe absence evidence alarm fatal knowledge think good good bye squire doctor captain be leave death starvation death hand mutineer

paragraph: All this while, as I say, I was still running, and without taking any notice, I had drawn near to the foot of the little hill with the two peaks and had got into a part of the island where the live-oaks grew more widely apart and seemed more like forest trees in their bearing and dimensions. Mingled with these were a few scattered pines, some fifty, some nearer seventy, feet high. The air too smelt more freshly than down beside the marsh.
tokens: while say run take notice draw foot little hill peak get part island live oak grow seem forest tree bear dimension mingle few scatter pine foot high air smell marsh

paragraph: And here a fresh alarm brought me to a standstill with a thumping heart.
tokens: fresh alarm bring standstill thump heart
